title: Drawing, "Elevation and Plan for a Staircase Model in the English Style", 1836
medium: Pen and black ink, brush and wash, watercolor on cream wove paper, ruled border with two lines in pen and black ink, brush and pink and green watercolor
inscribed: In pen and black ink, upper right: Fait à Paris le 10 février/ 1836 par Gillet Francoise (with paraph)
provenance: Angus Wilkie, Cove Landing; Eugene V. Thaw and Clare E. Thaw (as of 2007)
creditline: Gift of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw
description: Sectional elevation (above) and plan (below) for a twenty step 'English Style' spiral staircase. Starts as a single flight, and then splits into two curved sections before rejoining to form a single flight at the top.  Numbered annotations on each step.
justification: This well-executed drawing appears to correspond directly to one of the staircase models given to Cooper-Hewitt by Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw.&nbsp; The drawing, which&nbsp;shows both an elevation and a cross-section of the staircase's revolutions, represents an example of the compagnonnage training in design at a considerably earlier date than the other staircase drawings in Cooper-Hewitt's collection.&nbsp; With a date of 1836, the drawing demonstrates the continuum of this system of design training and of the forms taught.&nbsp; The inscription on the drawing also suggests that it was executed in Paris, which indicates that the work was probably completed to show design mastery in the journeyman phase.
